results.title: Child's toy tin magic lantern with candle projection
results.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Donated by William Kerr on behalf of Edwin Schefferle.
results.brief_description:
Magic Lantern with removable chimney and internal wooden block.

The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit was donated by Edwin Schefferle - “When Edwin was about 10 years of age, he acquired a Magic Lantern Outfit from his Grandma. This fired his imagination; he would make images with ink on strips of cellophane and project these through the Magic Lantern by means of a candle onto an old sheet draped on the wall. The result was disappointing but encouraging. The one candle did not provide sufficient light especially during daylight. Little did he realise that he had opened a door on a world of projecting images on large screens. He had abandoned merry-go-rounds and wind mills but this was different. He never let go of his Magic Lantern; it could well have been dubbed his lighthouse showing him the way to go. What happened to his Magic Lantern? After his death in 2014 it was found among his belongings and was donated to the Australian Centre for Moving Image (ACMI) which superseded the State Film Centre, where Edwin spent most of his working life.” (text from book - ‘Life with a Purpose, Conversations with Edwin James Schefferle - Scheff’)
results.title_for_label: Child’s toy tin magic lantern with candle projection

The result was disappointing but encouraging. The one candle did not provide sufficient light especially during daylight. Little did he realise that he had opened a door on a world of projecting images on large screens. He had abandoned merry-go-rounds and wind mills but this was different. He never let go of his Magic Lantern; it could well have been dubbed his lighthouse showing him the way to go. What happened to his Magic Lantern? results.title: Hand painted strip slide magic lantern with chimney
results.brief_description:
Hand painted strip slide magic lantern projector with chimney, and one set of hand painted glass slides (in restored condition).
Strip slide is a single sheet of glass with hand painting directly on to glass. Slide has a wooden frame (stable condition)
1 x Box containing projector
1 x Package containing glass slide (VERY FRAGILE)

results.title: Indigenous Voices on the Screen with Professor Gary Foley
results.brief_description: Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor, Professor Gary Foley charts the intersection of Indigenous activism and the world of film and TV in this short film by Yaegl director, producer and storyteller Pauline Clague.

constellations_primary.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_primary.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

results.title_for_label: Indigenous Voices on the Screen with Professor Gary Foley
results.description:
Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor, Professor Gary Foley charts the intersection of Indigenous activism and the world of film and TV in this short film by Yaegl director, producer and storyteller Pauline Clague. Through interviews, archival footage and scenes from film and TV, Foley explores the Black Power movement and the period during the 1970s and 80s when First Peoples began taking control of their representation in Australian screen culture, as well as how the moving image has been used to advocate for Indigenous Rights.

“It has been a journey recording Gary about the early years of film. How do you fit the wealth of information into an eight-minute space? I have had the privilege of recording many of the Indigenous trailblazers of the early years of television and film and know how important it is for us to remember those who made a mark on our landscape for us to dream, to make the films and stories we do now. As a person who loves their craft, I hope this gives you a glimpse of the power of our voices on-screen.” – Pauline Clague
description_for_label:
Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor, Professor Gary Foley charts the intersection of Indigenous activism and the world of film and TV in this short film by Yaegl director, producer and storyteller Pauline Clague. Through interviews, archival footage and scenes from film and TV, Foley explores the Black Power movement and the period during the 1970s and 80s when First Peoples began taking control of their representation in Australian screen culture, as well as how the moving image has been used to advocate for Indigenous Rights.

“It has been a journey recording Gary about the early years of film. How do you fit the wealth of information into an eight-minute space? I have had the privilege of recording many of the Indigenous trailblazers of the early years of television and film and know how important it is for us to remember those who made a mark on our landscape for us to dream, to make the films and stories we do now. As a person who loves their craft, I hope this gives you a glimpse of the power of our voices on-screen.” – Pauline Clague

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → 06. First Nations → MM-06-C01

results.title: WipEout 2097 for Sega Saturn
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM and manual in Sega Saturn case
results.brief_description: WipEout 2097 is set four decades after its predecessor. The F3600 anti-gravity racing competition from the first game has been replaced by an even faster and more dangerous tournament: the F5000 AG league. The racing and weapon use gameplay from the original WipEout remains the same. The main modes from have also returned, but with the addition of a new Challenge Modes. Completing challenges in this mode rewards the player with faster race speeds, new tracks, and new vehicles.

results.title: WipEout for Sega Saturn
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM and manual in Sega Saturn case
results.brief_description:
In the world of WipEout, anti-gravity racing is the world’s most popular sport. Tracks stretch out across the world and research is focused on finding even better and faster race craft. Racing for one of four corporations, the player competes to win the prestigious F3600 Anti-Gravity Racing League. Each corporation’s craft has its own strengths and weaknesses, which are further complicated by the choice of different pilots. Races aren’t simply affairs of speed and manoeuvring. The tracks are littered with weapons and powerups to hinder opponents or aid the player.

The game has three modes. Championship has the player attempting to place in the top three of each class, before proceeding to the next. If a player beats this mode in as the top of the Venom class, Rapier class, with tougher opponents, will be unlocked. Single Race pits the player against a full field of pilots in a single track. Time Trail is like single race, but without weapons.

results.title: Warlords III: Reign of Heroes for PC
results.creator_credit: Red Orb Entertainment and Strategic Studies Group
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case, advert, card game advert, registration card, troubleshooting guide, internet guide and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: The third instalment in the Warlords series boasts improved graphics throughout and retains much of the same turn-based strategy gameplay as its predecessors. The units a player can train are now not set to a specific clan, as new types of units from different clans can join the player’s faction. Also new to the series is the addition of diplomacy, where a player can forge treaties with others and conquer opponents together. This includes the ability to bribe others in order to influence their decisions. Lastly, while the game still allows for hotseat and play by email multiplayer, it now has the ability to play over the internet.
results.title_for_label: Warlords III: Reign of Heroes for PC
results.creator_credit_for_label: Red Orb Entertainment and Strategic Studies Group

The units a player can train are now not set to a specific clan, as new types of units from different clans can join the player’s faction. Also new to the series is the addition of diplomacy, where a player can forge treaties with others and conquer opponents together. This includes the ability to bribe others in order to influence their decisions. Lastly, while the game still allows for hotseat and play by email multiplayer, it now has the ability to play over the internet.
description_for_label: The third instalment in the Warlords series boasts improved graphics throughout and retains much of the same turn-based strategy gameplay as its predecessors. The units a player can train are now not set to a specific clan, as new types of units from different clans can join the player’s faction. Also new to the series is the addition of diplomacy, where a player can forge treaties with others and conquer opponents together. This includes the ability to bribe others in order to influence their decisions. Lastly, while the game still allows for hotseat and play by email multiplayer, it now has the ability to play over the internet.

results.brief_description: A stand-alone expansion to Warlords III: Reign of Heroes, Warlords III: Darklords Rising adds new campaigns and scenarios, an enhanced random map generator, and more heroes, units, and spells. Gameplay has also been changed to allow for simultaneous movements, a first in the series.

Gameplay has also been changed to allow for simultaneous movements, a first in the series.

Gameplay has also been changed to allow for simultaneous movements, a first in the series.
